awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrated Research and Education in Nonlinear Modal Decoupling and Control for Resilient Interconnected Power Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The conventional classification of power system stability has worked for decades in practice but will no longer be adequate on interconnected power systems with high penetration of intermittent renewable resources because some predefined stability categories such as small-signal stability and transient stability are no longer separate in real-life power system instabilities. In fact, stability assessment for a power system is a single nonlinear dynamic problem from the system point of view. However, a major technical gap lies in the current lack of fast, accurate stability analysis tools for complex, interconnected, nonlinear systems like power systems. This project aims at reducing that gap by establishing a new methodology for power system stability analysis and control based on understanding, decoupling and control of nonlinear modal dynamics. The outcomes of the project are expected to create broad impacts on both the power industry and research community. Fundamental theories established with the proposed new methodology can be generalized for other large-scale dynamic systems. The project will educate students at various levels in comprehending modal dynamics and nonlinearities inherent in interconnected power systems and train next-generation scientists and engineers to bring more nonlinear thinking to researching, designing and operating the future smart grid accommodating more renewable energy.

The research goals of the project include: (1) acquiring an in-depth understanding in nonlinear modal dynamics of an interconnected power system that are associated with invariant manifolds of the system state, (2) establishing a new approach for improving power system stability by nonlinear modal decoupling and control, and (3) boiling the new approach down to simple recipes such as practical tools for nonlinear modal analysis and stability monitoring of power systems. More specifically, the project will extend the concept of linear normal modes in small-signal stability analysis to nonlinear normal modes of power systems for global stability analysis, establish a theoretical foundation for natural decoupling and controlled decoupling of nonlinear normal modes based on the normal form method to structurally decompose the mathematical model of a power system, and propose innovative online stability assessment and control algorithms based on tracking and control of modal energy with nonlinear normal modes. This new methodology could be transformative to power system stability areas since the idea of understanding the nonlinear modes with power systems has not received enough attention in those areas and there is significant simplicity with stability analysis focusing on one or few modes compared to the original high-dimensional system model. Thus, the research of this project may point to a new avenue for faster-than-real-time stability assessment and control complementing the traditional computer simulation based approach.

por.por_cntn:
Nonlinear oscillations or vibrations are general phenomena of many real-world dynamical systems modeled as networks of nonlinear oscillators. Dynamics of such systems at large scales are fundamentally difficult to analyze. An example is a power grid as a complex network of a huge number of generators and motors, whose stability subject to a disturbance is analyzed in a state space of extremely high dimensionality. Although power system stability is a single problem, the academia and power industry have defined several classes of stability problems for simplification of analysis, under which simplified power system models can be used. For instance, ?small-signal stability? is studied using a linearized grid model while ?transient stability? is often analyzed on a nonlinear but reduced model to judge whether a large disturbance makes the system state escape from its domain of attraction. Such analyses on different classes of problems will no longer be adequate to a future power grid having a high penetration of power electronic inverter-based resources such as renewable generators because, first, the grid becomes much more complex and, second, the boundary between small and large disturbances is no longer clear. Alternative to analytical methods on power system stability, a power system simulator can numerically solve a detailed trajectory of the grid and then assess its stability but the result is only valid for the simulated operating condition and disturbance and can hardly provide information on stability margin. Also, simulation-based stability assessment can suffer from heavy computational burdens and hence is not suitable for real-time applications.

To address those challenges and enable fast and accurate global stability analysis for power grids as well as other nonlinear, multi-oscillator systems, this CAREER project has established a new methodology named Nonlinear Modal Decoupling (NMD). It inversely constructs as many decoupled nonlinear oscillators as the system?s oscillatory modes, whose nonlinearities are discovered by a new tool named ?Frequency-Amplitude Curve? that characterizes the energy-dependence of modal frequency. Those decoupled oscillators together provide a fairly accurate representation of the original system?s nonlinear dynamics around its equilibrium under large disturbances. Because each decoupled nonlinear oscillator has only one degree of freedom, it can easily be analyzed using, e.g., Lyapunov's direct method to evaluate the margin of the original system to instability regarding one mode. For future power grids, the NMD methodology provides a new paradigm of stability analysis and control by understanding, decomposition and control of nonlinear modal dynamics. On realistic, large-scale power system testbeds, an NMD-based real-time stability monitoring approach has been developed and validated. Because a majority of computation with NMD algorithms can be conducted offline and the real-time computation can focus on using wide-area measurements to locate the states of decoupled oscillators relative to their stability boundaries for a number of selected modes, a real-time stability assessment is achievable even for a large-scale power grid having many generators. To stabilize the grid against potential instability, the project has also developed a closed-loop control strategy that applies a data-driven NMD algorithm for real-time damping estimation for nonlinear oscillations under small and large disturbances and then utilizes distributed inverter-based resources for real-time direct damping feedback control.

The outcomes of the project can bring broad impacts on both the power industry and research community. Fundamental theories established with the new NMD methodology for stability analysis of power grids can be generalized for other nonlinear, multi-oscillator systems to benefit other disciplines. The education and research activities with this CAREER project have trained undergraduate and graduate students to bring more nonlinear thinking to the fields of power engineering and other engineering fields, and exposed them to real-world scientific and engineering problems and solutions.
